statement.p: Determine, with justification, all critical numbers of g.

hint.p: Where is g'(x) = 0? Is there anywhere that g'(x) is undefined?

answer.p: x = -4 and x = 2 are the only two critical numbers of g.

solution.p: Using the given fact that g'(x) = \frac{(x+4)(x-2)}{x^2+1}, we observe that since x^2 + 1 is never 0, g'(x) is never undefined. Moreover, g'(x) = 0 implies that (x+4)(x-2) = 0, which only happens when x = -4 or x = 2, so these are the two critical numbers of g.

statement.p: By developing a carefully labeled first derivative sign chart, decide whether g has as a local maximum, local minimum, or neither at each critical number.

hint.p: Choose values of x that lie just before and/or just after each of the critical numbers, and find the sign of g'(x) at each of them.

answer.p: For x \lt -4, g'(x) \gt 0; for -4 \lt x \lt 2, g'(x) \lt 0; and for x \gt 2, g'(x) \gt 0.

solution.p: We can observe that for x \lt -4, g'(x) \gt 0; for -4 \lt x \lt 2, g'(x) \lt 0; and for x \gt 2, g'(x) \gt 0.

statement.p: Does g have a global maximum? global minimum? Justify your claims.

hint.p: Are there x-values where g'(x) changes from negative to positive? positive to negative?

answer.p: g has a local maximum at x = -4; g has a local minimum at x = 2.

solution.p: Using the First Derivative Test and the signs of g'(x) we found in (b), it follows g has a local maximum at x = -4, since at that value g'(x) changes from positive to negative; similarly, g has a local minimum at x = 2 since there the derivative changes from negative to positive.
